label: Open permanent water
name_2: A1   Open permanent water surface that can receive rainwater
descr: Permanent water surface supplied rainwater from the site, regardless of whether this is a channel with concrete bottom stream with green banks or other type of water surface. Only the water surface is considered

label: Partially permeable
name_2: A2   Partially permeable serface like gravel, crushed stone, and reinforced grass surface
descr: Hard surfaces with permeability, providing infiltration. For example, grassy areas reinforced with concrete, gravel or crushed stone. Not surfaces of underlying hard covers if the soil depth is less than 80 cm.

label: Impermeable open drainage
name_2: A3   Impermeable surfaces with drainage to vegetated areas or an open drainage magazine
descr: Eg. concrete, asphalt, roofs and paving stones. Calculated for the area corresponding to the size of the vegetation surface that accepts water. The drainage magazine must have the capacity according to municipal requirements for discharges to official sewer system (ie it holds about 20 to 30 l / m² runoff area)

label: Impermeable closed drainage
name_2: A4   Impermeable surfaces with drainage to a local closed storm water drainage
descr: Eg. concrete, asphalt, roof surfaces with runoff led to a closed facility for retention and purification of the water. This also applies to underground solutions combined with irrigation of trees. The whole area counts assuming drainage magazine is according to municipal requirements for discharges to off. sewer system (ie it holds about 20 to 30 l / m² runoff area).

label: Drainage to groundwater
name_2: A5   Surfaces with vegetation associated with soil or bedrock
descr: Vegetation growing in  soil and has contact with the soil below. Beneficial for the development of flora and fauna and storm water can be pulled down to ground water. The point also applies to natural rock outcrops and cliffs.

label: Vegetation+soil > 80 cm
name_2: A6   Surfaces with vegetation, not associated with soil > 80 cm
descr: Vegetation growing in soil on minnimum 80 cm depth, but not in contact with the earth / ground below, eg. on top of a garage or roof. The depth is great enough that larger trees can grow.

label: Vegetation+soil 40-80 cm
name_2: A7   Surfaces with vegetation, not associated with soil 40 - 80 cm
descr: Vegetation growing in soil with 40-80 cm earth so that hedges, large bushes and small or medium trees can grow.

label: Vegetation+soil 20-40 cm
name_2: A8   Surfaces with vegetation, not associated with soil 20 - 40 cm
descr: Vegetation growing in soil with 20-40 cm earth for that  perennials and small bushes can grow.

label: Vegetation+soil 5-20 cm
name_2: A9   Surfaces with vegetation, not associated with soil 5 -20 cm
descr: Vegetation growing in soil with 5 - 20 cm earth that is enough for grasses, herbaceous plants and other ground cover can grow.

label: Natural water edge
name_2: B1   Natural edges to water srufaces
descr: Water surfaces that are counted above, can also be counted in this category there is access for flora / fauna at  ground level to a natural substrate and edge (riparian) zone. Eg: stream, canal and pond with green edges The area to be considered is the width of the water surface.

label: Rain bed
descr: Vegetation area that serves as rain bed or similar planted infiltration that collects, diffuses and infiltrates rainwater into the soil / ground. This does not apply to permanent water surfaces and diffusion basin counted in blue surfaces above.

name_1: Green additional qualities - trees (filled in as a number)
label: Closed canopy trees
name_2: C1   Closed canopy trees (% of total area)
descr: Total area of closed tree canopy.  Factor: closed_canopy_area m2/total_locality_area (x 1).

name_1: Green additional qualities - other (filled in as a m^2)
label: Native vegetaion
descr: Establishing or protection of surfaces with a large content of valuable plant species that are a part of the local, historical natural and cultural landscape.

name_1: Green additional qualities - other (filled in as a m^2)
label: Hedges, bushes
name_2: D2   Hedges, bushes and multi-stemmed trees
descr: Hedges, bushes and multi-stemmed trees with a height over 3 m. Calculated for a maximal area corresponding to the drip zone of (crown of the tree) m2/tree.

name_1: Green additional qualities - other (filled in as a m^2)
label: Green walls
descr: For climbing plants and other green walls, the factor is calculated for the wall area that can be expected to be covered over the course of 5 years (a maximum of 10 m height for climbing plants).

name_1: Green additional qualities - other (filled in as a m^2)
label: Perennial vegetation
name_2: D4   Perinnials and other ground cover
descr: Does not apply to lawn grasses

name_1: Green additional qualities - other (filled in as a m^2)
label: Contiguous green area
name_2: D5   Contiguous green areas over 75 m2
descr: Contiguous green area that is larger than 75 m2, as for example large grassy lawns, pllanted areas, or others.

name_1: Connectivity of structures (filled in with the number 0,05)
label: Connectivity
name_2: E1   Connectivity to an existing Blue-green structure.
descr: If the blue and / or green elements in the area can be connected to the existing structure outside the area in question. The connectivity should be obvious. For example, a stream opening, a link to the existing channel or water surface, drainage, the extension of an alley or a grove, merging of several courtyards with free movement between them. This provides a general increase of 0.05 in BGF.
